questions.text: A 32-year- female with a 1-year history of diabetes, presented to the hospital casualty with a 2 days history of weakness, nausea and vomiting. All of the following are biochemical features suggestive of the diagnosis EXCEPT?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Venous bicarbonate 20 mmol/L Metabolic acidosis (venous bicarbonate < 15 mmol/L and/ or venous pH < 7.3 (H+>50 nmol/L).

Highyeild:

The cardinal biochemical features of DKA are: Hyperketonaemia (≥ 3.0 mmol/L) or ketonuria (more than2+ on standard urine sticks) Hyperglycemia (blood glucose ≥ 11 mmol/L (approximately200 mg/dL)) Metabolic acidosis (venous bicarbonate < 15 mmol/L and/or venous pH < 7.3 (H+ > 50nmol/L)).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Hyperglycaemia (blood glucose ≥ 11 mmol/L (approximately 200 mg/dL)) Option: B : Hyperketonemia (≥ 3.0 mmol/L) or ketonuria (more than 2+ on standard urine sticks) Option: D : Metabolic acidosis (venous bicarbonate < 15 mmol/L and/ or venous pH < 7.3 (H+ > 50 nmol/L).

questions.text: A young pregnant female with K/C/O type 1 diabetes presents to emergency with symptoms of UTI, nausea, pain abdomen and RBS of 220 mg%. Urine is positive for ketones. Which of the following is false about her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The magnitude of the hyperglycaemia correlates with the severity of the metabolic acidosis

options.label: B
options.text: Type 1 diabetes in pregnancy is one situation where DKA can occur with blood glucose levels that are not especially high

options.label: C
options.text: DKA may be precipitated by an intercurrent illness

options.label: D
options.text: In young patients with recurrent episodes of DKA, may have psychological problems complicated by eating disorders

questions.correct_answer: A. The magnitude of the hyperglycaemia correlates with the severity of the metabolic acidosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The magnitude of the hyperglycaemia correlates with the severity of the metabolic acidosis The magnitude of the hyperglycaemia does not correlate with the severity of the metabolic acidosis; moderate elevation of blood glucose may be associated with life-threatening ketoacidosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B: Type 1 diabetes in pregnancy is one situation where DKA can occur with blood glucose levels that are not especially high. Conversely, in other situations, hyperglycaemia predominates and acidosis is minimal, with patients presenting in a hyperosmolar state. Option: C: DKA may be precipitated by an intercurrent illness because of failure to increase insulin dose appropriately to compensate for the stress response. Option: D : In young patients with recurrent episodes of DKA, up to 20% may have psychological problems complicated by eating disorders.

questions.text: A 32-year diabetic male patient presented to the hospital casualty with a 2 days history of weakness, nausea and vomiting. Rbs of 350 mg and ketones are present in urine. He is suspected of diabetic ketoacidosis. All of the following are biochemical features suggestive of severe diabetic ketoacidosis except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glasgow Coma Scale score 13 Glasgow Coma Scale score <12 or an abnormal AVPU scale is an indicator.

Highyeild:

20.15 Indicators of severe diabetic ketoacidosis ● Blood ketones >6 mmol/L ● Bicarbonate <5 mmol/L ● Venous/arterial pH <7.0 (H + >100 nmol/L) ● Hypokalaemia on admission (<3.5 mmol/L) ● Glasgow Coma Scale score <12 (p. 194) or abnormal AVPU scale score (p. 188) ● O 2 saturation <92% on air ● Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg ● Heart rate >100 or <60 beats per minute ● Anion gap >16 mmol/

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A : Heart rate >100 or <60 beats per minute. Option: B: Venous/arterial pH <7.0 (H+>100 nmol/L). Option: D: Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg.

questions.text: A 28-year diabetic female patient presents with features suggestive of DKA. Which of the following is an indicator of severe DKA?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anion gap 22 mmol/L Anion gap >16 mmol/L indicates severe DKA.

Highyeild:

20.15 Indicators of severe diabetic ketoacidosis ● Blood ketones >6 mmol/L ● Bicarbonate <5 mmol/L ● Venous/arterial pH <7.0 (H + >100 nmol/L) ● Hypokalaemia on admission (<3.5 mmol/L) ● Glasgow Coma Scale score <12 (p. 194) or abnormal AVPU scale score (p. 188) ● O 2 saturation <92% on air ● Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg ● Heart rate >100 or <60 beats per minute ● Anion gap >16 mmol/

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Blood ketones >6 mmol/L. Option: B: Bicarbonate <5 mmol/L. Option: C: Hypokalaemia on admission (<3.5 mmol/L).

questions.text: A 25-year diabetic male is diagnosed with DKA with a systolic BP of 100 mmHg. Which of the following is true about initial hour fluid resuscitation in the patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Give 1 L 0.45% sodium chloride over 60 mins

options.label: B
options.text: Give 1 L 0.9% sodium chloride over 60 mins

options.label: C
options.text: Give 500 mL 0.45% sodium chloride over 10–15 mins, then re-assess

options.label: D
options.text: Give 500 mL 0.9% sodium chloride over 10–15 mins, then re-assess

questions.correct_answer: B. Give 1 L 0.9% sodium chloride over 60 mins
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Give 1 L 0.9% sodium chloride over 60 mins Commence 0.9% sodium chloride: If systolic BP > 90 mmHg, give 1 L over 60 mins If systolic BP < 90 mmHg, give 500 mL over 10–15 mins, then re-assess; if BP remains < 90 mmHg, repeat and seek senior review. Option: A: C: 0.9% sodium chloride is used NOT half NS. Option: D: If systolic BP < 90 mmHg.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man came with a blurring of vision. Urine examination shows proteinuria. On performing a fundus examination there were dot and blood haemorrhages, microaneurysm, and cotton wool spots. Following is the histopathology of the kidney, identify the Image
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nodular glomerulosclerosis History suggests diabetic nephropathy Histopathology Image shows pas positive nodules suggestive of Kimmelstiel Wilson lesion or intercapillary glomerulosclerosis is pathognomic of diabetic nephropathy Progression of changes in diabetic nephropathy Thickening of the gbm is a sensitive indicator for the presence of diabetes but correlates poorly with the presence or absence of clinically significant nephropathy The expansion of the mesangium due to the accumulation of extracellular matrix correlates with the clinical manifestations of diabetic nephropathy This expansion in the mesangial matrix is associated with the development of mesangial sclerosis. Some patients also develop eosinophilic, pas+ nodules called nodular glomerulosclerosis or kimmelstiel-wilson nodules.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Fibrin cap is an accumulation of hyaline material attached to the capillary loop Option: B . Armani Ebstein reaction is a collection of glycogen clumps within renal tubules Option: C . Capsular drop is accumulation in bowman capsule

questions.text: Mrs Pinto, 36 years old came with hypertension, increased weight and easy bruisability. On examination the following clinical feature is seen, a screening test for diagnosing the following disease includes all except
questions.correct_answer: D. Determination of plasma acth levels
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Determination of plasma acth levels Determination of plasma ACTH levels is not a screening test for Cushing’s syndrome. It is used in the differential diagnosis of ACTH-dependent or independent Cushing’s syndrome

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Overnight dexamethasone suppression tes t It is the correct option, confirmation test is plasma cortisol > 50 nmol/l at 8-9 am after 1 mg dexamethasone at 11 pm Option B. Midnight plasma cortisol measurement >130 nmol/l plasma cortisol level is confirmatory Option C . 24-hour free cortisol excretion measurement 3 x increase is confirmatory

questions.text: A 52-year-diabetic male presented to the hospital casualty with clinical findings suggestive of HHS. All of the following are biochemical features of HHS EXCEPT?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

pH 7.2 HHS is characterised without significant ketonaemia (<3 mmol/L) or acidosis (pH >7.3 (H+ <50 nmol/L), bicarbonate >15 mmol/L) .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Serum osmolality > 320 mOsmol/kg. Option: C: Bicarbonate >15 mmol/L. Option: D: Severe hyperglycaemia (> 30 mmol/L (600 mg/dL).
